sentences.text: The '''2025 Africa Cup of Nations''', also referred to as '''AFCON 2025''' or '''CAN 2025''', is scheduled to be the 35th edition of the biennial African association football|football tournament organised by the Confederation of African Football (CAF). It will be hosted by Morocco for the second time and the first since 1988 African Cup of Nations|1988. Morocco was originally scheduled to host 2015 Africa Cup of Nations|the 2015 edition, but withdrew due to fears stemming from the Western African Ebola virus epidemic.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-06-21 |title=AFCON moves to winter due to Club World Cup |url=https://africa.espn.com/football/story/_/id/40402895/africa-cup-nations-2025-winter-club-world-cup |access-date=2024-06-24 |website=ESPN.com |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|date=21 February 2024|title=AFCON 2025 gets summer dates in Morocco|url=https://www.afrik-foot.com/en-ng/afcon-2025-gets-summer-dates-in-morocco|website=Afrik Foot|access-date=10 March 2024}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|date=20 February 2024|title=AFCON 2025 to be scheduled forJuly-August 2025 in Morocco|url=https://www.africanews.com/2024/02/20/afcon-2025-to-be-scheduled-forjuly-august-2025-in-morocco|website=africanews|access-date=10 March 2024}}</ref>

sentences.text: Due to FIFA expanding its FIFA Club World Cup|Club World Cup competition to 32 teams and having it 2025 FIFA Club World Cup|scheduled for June and July that year, this edition of the tournament will be played between 21 December 2025 and 18 January 2026. The situation has been further complicated by the addition of two extra match days scheduled for the last two weeks of January in the expanded Champions League that begins this season in Europe.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Aarons |first=Ed |last2=Molina |first2=Romain |last3=Aarons |first3=Exclusive by Ed |date=2024-06-12 |title=Afcon could move to December 2025 to avoid Club World Cup clash |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/article/2024/jun/12/afcon-could-move-to-december-2025-to-avoid-club-world-cup-clash |access-date=2024-06-21 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite press release|date=3 July 2022|title=CAF President Dr Motsepe announces African Super League launch details, AFCON 2023 and Champions League key decisions|url=https://www.cafonline.com/press-release/news/caf-president-dr-motsepe-announces-african-super-league-launch-details-afcon2023|publisher=Confederation of African Football|CAFOnline.com|access-date=3 June 2023|quote=...the Executive Committee has decided that this edition of the tournament (the 2023 edition) will be postponed to the months of January and February 2024. The postponement is as a direct and sole result of the adverse weather conditions in the country and after also having received further technical opinion from experts on adverse effects of staging the matches in that period, as June and July are rainy seasons in Ivory Coast. |archive-date=3 July 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220703210736/https://www.cafonline.com/press-release/news/caf-president-dr-motsepe-announces-african-super-league-launch-details-afcon2023 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: This edition of the tournament was scheduled to be the second after 2019 Africa Cup of Nations|2019 to take place during the northern hemisphere's summer (June-July), in order to reduce scheduling conflicts with European club teams and competitions; the previous 2023 Africa Cup of Nations|2023 edition was moved to January and February 2024 owing to the adverse summer weather conditions in Ivory Coast. Guinea was originally set as hosts for this edition of the tournament, but had its hosting rights stripped after affirming its inadequacy of hosting preparations. After a second bidding process, Ivory Coast national football team|Ivory Coast are 2023 Africa Cup of Nations final|the defending champions.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|date=21 July 2017|title=Africa Cup of Nations to switch from January staging to June in 2019|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/jul/20/africa-cup-nations-staging-expansion|website=The Guardian|access-date=20 July 2018}}</ref>

<ref name="Reopen" /> Morocco was named as the new hosts on 27 September 2023.<ref name="2025Host">{{cite web|date=27 September 2023|title=Morocco to host 2025 Africa Cup of Nations|url=https://www.cafonline.com/news/morocco-to-host-2025-africa-cup-of-nations/|website=Confederation of African Football|CAFOnline.com|access-date=2 October 2023 }}</ref>

<ref name="MOTM">{{cite web |date=12 February 2024 |title=Nigeria 1â€“2 Ivory Coast: Sebastien Haller seals Africa Cup of Nations final comeback for host nation |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/13067540/nigeria-1-2-ivory-coast-sebastien-haller-seals-africa-cup-of-nations-final-comeback-for-host-nation |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240212225657/https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/13067540/nigeria-1-2-ivory-coast-sebastien-haller-seals-africa-cup-of-nations-final-comeback-for-host-nation |archive-date=12 February 2024 |accessdate=15 February 2024 |work=Sky Sports}}</ref>

sentences.text: CAF stripped Cameroon from hosting 2019 Africa Cup of Nations|the 2019 edition of the tournament on 30 November 2018 due lack of speed of progress in preparations, but accepted former CAF president Ahmad Ahmad's request to stage 2021 Africa Cup of Nations|the next edition in 2021. Consequently, the original hosts of 2021, Ivory Coast, became hosts of 2023 Africa Cup of Nations|the 2023 edition with Guinea instead hosting the 2025 edition, which until then had no hosts. The CAF President confirmed the timetable shift after a meeting with Ivorian president Alassane Ouattara in Abidjan, Ivory Coast on 30 January 2019. On 30 September 2022, current CAF president Patrice Motsepe announced that Guinea had been stripped as host for the 2025 edition due to inadequacy and speed of progress in hosting preparations. Consequently, a new process was re-opened for a replacement host bidder. On 27 September 2023, the 2025 edition was awarded to Morocco

sentences.text: The qualifiers were held between 20 March and 19 November 2024, starting with the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations qualification preliminary round|preliminary round (20â€“26 March 2024) and then the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations qualification#Group stage|group stage (2 Septemberâ€“19 November 2024). The preliminary round draw was held on 20 February 2024, 14:00 Central Africa Time|CAT (UTC+02:00|UTC+2) at the CAF headquarters in Cairo, Egypt. The eight involved national teams were seeded into two pots of four based on the FIFA World Rankings from 15 February 2024,  Seychelles national football team|Seychelles and Eritrea national football team|Eritrea were excluded from the qualifiers. The eight teams were split into four ties which were played in home-and-away Two-legged tie|two-legged format. The group stage draw took place on 4 July 2024, 14:30 Central Africa Time|CAT (UTC+02:00|UTC+2) in Johannesburg, South Africa. The 48 national teams involved were divided into twelve groups of four each, which consisted of the 44 teams that entered directly, in addition to the four winners of the preliminary round, and were seeded into four pots of twelve each based on the June 2024 FIFA Men's World Rankings|FIFA World Rankings.

sentences.text: The following teams qualified for this edition, all of them have previously participated in the tournament. Morocco national football team|Morocco, the host country, played in the qualifiers in 2025 Africa Cup of Nations qualification Group B|Group B despite qualifying automatically. Ghana national football team|Ghana, four-time African champions, failed to qualify after finishing bottom of the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations qualification Group F|Group F, missing out on the Africa Cup of Nations for the first time since 2004 African Cup of Nations|2004. Tunisia national football team|Tunisia qualified for the 22nd time and extended their record for consecutive participations, reaching the tournament for the 17th time in a row, having not been absent since 1994 African Cup of Nations|1994. Comoros national football team|Comoros, Gabon national football team|Gabon, Sudan national football team|Sudan and Zimbabwe national football team|Zimbabwe made their return to the continental tournament after missing out on 2023 Africa Cup of Nations|2023. Benin national football team|Benin and Uganda national football team|Uganda made their return after an almost five-year absence from the event. Botswana national football team|Botswana qualified for the second time after their first participation in 2012 Africa Cup of Nations|2012. Cape Verde national football team|Cape Verde, Gambia national football team|Gambia, Guinea national football team|Guinea, Guinea-Bissau national football team|Guinea-Bissau, Mauritania national football team|Mauritania and Namibia national football team|Namibia also failed to qualify after appearing in 2023 Africa Cup of Nations|2023.

On 27 January 2025, The Confederation of African Football  (CAF) together with Royal Moroccan Football Federation and the Local Organizing Committee of the TotalEnergies CAF Africa Cup of Nations, Morocco 2025 announced the 9 venues in 6 cities that will host matches in the competition.
